body:
# Safe Navigation Operator This blog is for demonstrating the Safe Navigation Operator(?.) **Safe Navigation Operator(?.)** is already present in other scripting languages i.e. `Groovy` and there it is known as **Null-Safe Dereference**. First lets understand what is the scenario. A common error which we face a lot(`Cannot read property 'propertyName' of undefined`) in **JavaScript**, if we tried to read property on a undefined object. i.e. ```JavaScript var user; console.log(user.name); // Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'name' of undefined ``` To handle this error, we add check for **user** object, if user is defined then only we read the name i.e.: ```JavaScript var user; if (user) { console.log(user.name); // Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'name' of undefined } ``` In **AngularJS**, we write **JavaScript** into **HTML/View**. And in **AngularJS 1.X**, it silently fails, if user object is not defined and does not display any thing. ```HTML
User Details: Name: {{user.name}} Age: {{user.age}}
``` But in **Angular2**, it will throw an error `Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'name' of undefined`. So we have to add extra check before reading the property from object: ```HTML
User Details: Name: {{user && user.name}} Age: {{user && user.age}}
``` So **Angular2** have introduced **Safe Navigation Operator(?.)** for the same. With (?.) our code will be more smaller and readable: ```HTML
User Details: Name: {{user?.name}} Age: {{user?.age}}
``` > `Safe Navigation Operator(?.)` is used to avoid error `Cannot read property 'propertyName' of undefined`. Typically when we have a reference of an object and we might need to verify that it is not **undefined** before accessing the property the object.
